questions.question:
Question 1: A 36-year-old woman presented with intermittent suprapubic pain, increased urinary 
frequency, and dysuria for 2 months. A cystoscopy revealed the presence of Hunner ulcers. 
What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Hunner ulcers are chronic mucosal ulcers that are characteristic of interstitial cystitis or chronic 
pelvic pain syndrome. 847 
Sold by @itachibot It is a rare idiopathic condition that occurs most frequently in women. It presents with 
intermittent severe suprapubic pain, urinary frequency, urgency, hematuria, and dysuria. The following cystoscopic findings are seen in the bladder mucosa: • Fissures • Punctate hemorrhages (glomerulations) The microscopic findings include: • Mucosal ulceration covered by fibrin and necrotic material • Increased numbers of mucosal mast cells • Submucosal edema In later stages, transmural fibrosis may occur, leading to a contracted bladder. Biopsy must be 
done to rule out carcinoma in situ, which may clinically mimic interstitial cystitis. The following image shows a Hunner's ulcer in a patient with interstitial cystitis.

questions.question:
Question 2: A 31-year-old man presented with a history of recurrent UTIs and hematuria. Urine culture 
showed growth of E. coli. Flexible cystoscopy revealed yellow-brown soft plaques with a 
central umbilication. Microscopy of the plaque showed Michaelis-Gutmann bodies. What is 
the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario with the presence of Michaelis-Gutmann bodies is suggestive of 
malakoplakia. Malakoplakia is a chronic inflammatory reaction resulting from acquired defects in phagocyte 
function, commonly affecting the urinary bladder. It can also be seen in other organ systems like 
the gastrointestinal tract, female genital tract, and central nervous system. It is seen in chronic bacterial infection, mostly by Escherichia coli or occasionally Proteus 
species. Grossly, it presents as soft, yellow-brown, slightly raised mucosal plaques. Microscopically, the 
following findings are seen: 848 
Sold by @itachibot • Large, foamy macrophages containing - • Abundant granular cytoplasm due to undigested bacterial products • Michaelis-Gutmann bodies - PAS-positive basophilic concretions due to iron and calcium 
deposits in lysosomes • Occasional multinucleated giant cells and lymphocytes Note: Xanthogranulomatous cystitis is morphologically and probably pathogenetically similar to 
malakoplakia, but it lacks Michaelis–Gutmann bodies.

questions.question: Question 3: What is the most common cause of polypoid cystitis?
questions.explanation:
The most common cause of polypoid cystitis is indwelling catheters. Polypoid cystitis is an inflammatory lesion resulting from mucosal irritation. It may also be 
associated with radiation therapy and malignant tumors. It usually involves the posterior wall of 
the bladder. Grossly, it may show bulbous or papillary appearance and may be confused with papillary 
urothelial carcinoma. Microscopically, the papillary projections are broad-based, non-branching, 
and without atypia. Stroma is edematous with minimal inflammation. Options A and D: Adenovirus infection and the use of anti-cancer drugs like cyclophosphamide 
cause hemorrhagic cystitis. Option B: Systemic allergic disorders cause eosinophilic cystitis.

questions.question:
Question 4: 844 
Sold by @itachibot A pathologist observed a metaplastic lesion in a biopsy sample taken from the bladder 
mucosa of a patient. Which of the following is not a differential diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
849 
Sold by @itachibot Malakoplakia is not a metaplastic lesion of the bladder. It is a type of chronic granulomatous 
cystitis due to defective phagocytic function that may mimic malignancy. Metaplastic lesions of the bladder include the following: • Nests of urothelium (Brunn nests) may grow downward into the lamina propria resulting in the 
following lesions - • Cystitis glandularis - epithelial cells in the center of the nest undergo metaplasia and take on a 
cuboidal or columnar appearance • Cystitis cystica - epithelial cells retract to produce cystic spaces lined by flattened urothelium • Squamous metaplasia - in response to injury, urothelium is replaced by stratified squamous 
epithelium. • Nephrogenic adenoma - due to implantation of shed renal tubular cells at sites of injured 
urothelium, resulting in replacement of urothelium by cuboidal epithelium with a papillary 
growth pattern

questions.question: Question 5: What is the most common tumor of the urinary bladder?
questions.explanation:
The most common tumor of the urinary bladder is transitional cell carcinoma or urothelial 
carcinoma. Other epithelial tumors like squamous cell carcinoma, adenocarcinoma, and small cell carcinoma 
may also occur. Sarcomas are distinctly uncommon in the bladder. However, the most common sarcoma in 
infancy or childhood is embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma, and the most common sarcoma in the 
bladder in adults is leiomyosarcoma.

questions.question:
Question 6: A 57-year-old man presented with chronic hematuria and dysuria. Microscopic examination 
of urine showed the following parasitic eggs. What type of bladder carcinoma is commonly 
associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
The image shows oval-shaped eggs with the terminal spine which is characteristic of Schistosoma 
haematobium. It is most commonly associated with squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder. The ova are deposited in the bladder wall and incite a brisk chronic inflammatory response. This 
induces progressive mucosal squamous metaplasia and dysplasia and, in some instances, 
neoplasia. Schistosomal infection can less frequently result in adenocarcinoma or transitional cell 
carcinoma.

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following is not a carcinogen for bladder cancer?
questions.explanation:
Isopropyl alcohol is not implicated in the causation of bladder cancer. Benzidine, arylamines, and phenacetin are well-established risk factors for bladder cancer. 850 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following genetic changes is not associated with bladder carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
Activating mutation in HRAS (not NRAS) is responsible for bladder carcinoma. Genetic changes associated with carcinoma bladder: • Noninvasive low-grade papillary urothelial carcinoma is associated with: • Gain-of-function mutations of FGFR3 and HRAS genes • Chromosome 9p and 9q deletions • High-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma (either papillary or flat) is associated with: • Loss-of-function mutations of TP53 and RB genes Note: Erdafitinib (kinase inhibitor) is the first targeted drug therapy approved by the FDA for the 
treatment of metastatic urothelial carcinoma especially in patients with mutations of FGFR3 or 
FGFR2.

questions.question: Question 9: The most consistent and persistent feature of bladder carcinoma is:
questions.explanation:
The most consistent and persistent feature of carcinoma bladder is painless hematuria. Bladder tumors produce a wide range of clinical features including: • Painless hematuria - classical feature and may be the only clinical manifestation • Irritative urinary symptoms (frequency, urgency, dysuria) - diffuse tumors or tumors at the 
bladder neck • Pyelonephritis or hydronephrosis - when the ureteral orifice is involved • Obstructive symptoms, palpable suprapubic mass, or lower extremity edema - late 
presentation with a large tumor mass • Weight loss and/or localized bone pain - metastatic disease

questions.question:
Question 10: Which of the following is not included in the latest International Society of Urological 
Pathology grading of urothelial tumors?

options.b: Urothelial neoplasm of low malignant potential

questions.explanation:
International Society of Urological Pathology (ISUP) grading system classifies papillary urothelial 
carcinoma into 2 grades - low grade and high grade. The classification of papillary urothelial 
carcinoma into grades 1, 2, 3 was was part of the earlier WHO classification. Grading of urothelial (transitional cell) tumors: WHO/ISUP grades: • Urothelial papilloma • Urothelial neoplasm of low malignant potential 851 
Sold by @itachibot • Papillary urothelial carcinoma, low grade • Papillary urothelial carcinoma, high grade WHO grades (old classification): • Urothelial papilloma • Urothelial neoplasm of low malignant potential • Papillary urothelial carcinoma, grade 1 • Papillary urothelial carcinoma, grade 2 • Papillary urothelial carcinoma, grade 3

questions.question:
Question 11: A 67-year-old chronic smoker with gross painless hematuria was diagnosed with infiltrating 
urothelial carcinoma. What is the most important prognostic factor for his condition?
questions.explanation:
The staging (extent of spread) at the time of initial diagnosis is the most important prognostic 
factor in infiltrating urothelial carcinoma. The prognosis of bladder carcinoma depends on the histologic grade and the stage at diagnosis. As 
most infiltrating urothelial carcinomas are high-grade, staging becomes the major factor to 
determine the prognosis. 852 
Sold by @itachibot Female Genital Tract
